[[Harmony Company|Harmony Stratotone]]
[[Guild Guitar Company|Guild Thunderbird]] }} '''Daniel Quine "Dan" Auerbach''' (born May 14, 1979) is an American musician and record producer best known as the [[guitarist]] and [[singing|vocalist]] for [[The Black Keys]], a [[blues rock]] band from [[Akron, Ohio]].[http://www.quine.org/quine.html Quine Genealogy 10 Generations by Douglas Boynton Quine]. Quine.org. Retrieved on 2011-05-10. As a member of the band, Auerbach has recorded and co-produced seven studio albums with his bandmate [[Patrick Carney]]. In 2009, Auerbach released a solo album entitled ''[[Keep It Hid]]''. In addition to winning several [[Grammy Award]]s as a member of The Black Keys, Auerbach received the 2013 [[Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical]] for co-producing his band's 2011 album ''[[El Camino (The Black Keys album)|El Camino]]'', and for producing records by [[Dr. John]] (''[[Locked Down (album)|Locked Down]]'') and Hacienda. ==Childhood and early life== Auerbach was born in Ohio, and is the son of Mary Little (née Quine; b. about 1948), a teacher of French, and Charles Auerbach (b. about 1950), an antique dealer.{{cite news|author=Dave Simpson |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2011/dec/01/black-keys-interview |title='We've put in more hours than anyone': The Black Keys interviewed | Music |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2011-12-01|accessdate=2012-05-23 |location=London}} His father is of [[Polish Jewish]] descent and his mother is of part [[Manx people|Manx]] descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.quine.org/quine.html |title=Quine Genealogy 10 Generations by Douglas Boynton Quine |publisher=Quine.org |date= |accessdate=2012-05-23}} His maternal cousin, twice removed, was philosopher and logician [[Willard Van Orman Quine]], and his second cousin once removed was the late guitarist [[Robert Quine]]. Auerbach grew up in a family with musical roots. Auerbach became infatuated with [[blues]] after listening to his father's old [[vinyl recording|vinyl records]] during his childhood.[http://www.guitarplayer.com/article/the-black-keys/Nov-03/1580 The Black Keys’ Guitar Player – Dan Auerbach on the Majesty of Muck] He was influenced early-on by his mother's side of the family, notably his uncles who played [[bluegrass music]]. Auerbach described himself as a normal teenager in high school who smoked [[marijuana]] and captained the soccer team at [[Firestone High School]].Usinger, Mike. (2011-05-05) [http://archives.nodepression.com/2006/09/modern-primitives/ The Black Keys – Modern Primitives « Americana and Roots Music – No Depression]. Archives.nodepression.com. Retrieved on 2011-05-10. He was heavily influenced by [[Junior Kimbrough]] in college, eventually resulting in his dropping out to pursue the guitar more seriously. "I've listened to him so much, it's just how I hear it... I studied him so much... Getting F's in college, when I should've been studying, I was listening to Junior Kimbrough's music instead".[http://www.popmatters.com/music/interviews/black-keys-050202.shtml PopMatters Music Interview – Cold Steel in the Midnight Hour: An Interview with Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys] Other major influences include: [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]], [[R.L. Burnside]], [[Clarence White]], [[Robert Nighthawk]], [[T-Model Ford]], [[Hound Dog Taylor]], [[Mississippi Fred McDowell]], [[Kokomo Arnold]], [[Son House]] and [[RZA]] of the [[Wu Tang Clan]]. ==Performances and bands== ===The Barnburners=== Auerbach was a member of a band called The Barnburners before forming [[The Black Keys]] in 2001.[http://theblackkeysfanlounge.com/2010/01/meet-me-in-the-city-junior-kimbrough-vs-the-barnburners-vs-the-black-keys/] Meet Me In The City: Junior Kimbrough vs The Barnburners vs The Black Keys. Retrieved on 2011-05-12. The Barnburners included Auerbach, Jason Edwards and Kip Amore. The Barnburners were a [[blues]]-based band that performed in [[Greater Cleveland|Northeast Ohio]] clubs and released a 6 track album called The Rawboogie EP. The album includes the [[Junior Kimbrough]] song "Meet Me in the City", which Auerbach later covered with [[The Black Keys]] on their [[Chulahoma: The Songs of Junior Kimbrough|Chulahoma]] studio album. [[File:Dan Auerbach playing House of Blues, New Orleans.jpg|thumb|left|Dan Auerbach and the Fast Five playing the House of Blues in New Orleans, Louisiana, on November 18, 2009.]] ===The Fast Five=== The band "Fast Five" toured with Auerbach in 2009. The Fast Five's other members drew from the band Hacienda and percussionist [[Patrick Hallahan]] from [[My Morning Jacket]].{{cite news|title=Out of the Garage with Hacienda|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=122765682}}[http://www.amazon.com/dp/B002TDV73K] Fast Five concert poster{{cite web|last=The Fast Five|first=Dan Auerbach|title= Dan Auerbach and the Fast Five @ Boogie Festival, Tallarook |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hlmgzz7Inek|work=Concert video|publisher=YouTube|date=11 April 2009}}{{cite news|last=Oliphint|first=Joel|title=Auerbach goes solo—with five other guys|url=http://www.theotherpaper.com/articles/2009/11/11/music/doc4afb45391fd58994411517.txt|accessdate=19 July 2010|newspaper=The Other Paper|date=11 November 2009}} The original percussionist, Bob Cesare, was unable to perform with the Fast Five due to a death in his family.http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2009/02/my_morning_jack_15.html Dan and fellow Black Keys member [[Patrick Carney]] met the members of Hacienda at a club, [[Emo's]], in Austin, Texas while watching a band during the [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]].[http://theblackkeysfanlounge.com/2010/08/the-black-keys-and-hacienda-a-love-story/] The Black Keys Fan Lounge. Retrieved on 2011-05-12. Upon seeing one of the Hacienda band members hit on an intoxicated woman, Carney walked over and leaned in saying, "Dude, trust me, that's a bad idea." After becoming acquainted with each other, Dan e-mailed Hacienda a month later asking for more demos, which eventually led them to being asked to open for The Black Keys and [[Dr. Dog]] at a show in Austin, Texas. Afterward, Auerbach asked Hacienda to travel to Akron, Ohio where they would be his "Guinea pigs" while recording ''[[Keep It Hid]]''. {{Clear}} ==Awards and Honors== At the [[2013 Grammy Awards]], Auerbach won the award for [[Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical|Producer of the Year, Non-Classical]].{{cite web | url=http://kroq.cbslocal.com/2013/02/10/dan-auerbach-steals-grammy-from-pop-super-producer-diplo/ |title=Dan Auerbach Steals GRAMMY From Pop Super-Producer Diplo }} In 2010, he joined the 9th annual [[Independent Music Awards]] judging panel to assist independent musicians' careers. ==Personal life== Auerbach was married to Stephanie Gonis, with whom he has a daughter, Sadie Little Auerbach, born in 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/black-day-for-auerbach/story-fnejlvvj-1226576417835|title=Black day for Auerbach|work=news.com.au|publisher=[[News Limited]]|date=2013-02-12|accessdate=2013-02-12}} In February 2013, it was reported that the couple are in the midst of divorce proceedings.http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/dan-auerbach-black-keys-frontman-splits-with-wife-stephanie-gonis-2013112 ==Discography== [[File:Dan Auerbach of Black Keys at Music Midtown
